title: Home
text:
Hi! I’m Will Decker and welcome to my website. Check out the pages to learn more about me and my science. If you are a first time visitor, please check out the About Me section to learn more about my current status, research interests and personal life. If you are looking for some of my projects, please check out My Open Science and Projects where you will find direct access to my science.
If you would like to contact me, please email jdecke5(at)lsu(dot)edu or deckerwill7(at)gmail(dot)com.
I have a twitter too!

title: Open Science
text:
Open science is integral to creating good science. Adherence to such practices supports the transparent dissemination of information which concurrently increases the trust in the scientific community and allows research to be replicated and validated. Thusly, I have included some resources that I’ve found seminal in my personal development and understanding of what it means to conduct open science as well as the sites that I use to share the research that I am a part of and conduct.
Open science is a multi-tiered practice that consists of multiple concepts like reproducibility, accessibility, transparency, diversity and analytical rigor. It cannot simply be described in one paragraph and to understand it requires much more than the resources I’ve provided. I am still learning and will be continuing to learn about open science.

title: Open Science
text:
Resources
The resources listed below are some of the many that have influenced my drive for open science and aided in my ability to conduct open science. If you have other sources of knowledge regarding open science and its implementation, please reach out!

Psychology needs to get tired of winning. (Haeffel 2022).
EEG is better left alone (Delorme 2023)
Science has a nasty photoshopping problem (Bik 2022)
Brain Imaging Data Structure (BIDS)
Center for Open Science

title: About Me
text:
Most notably, my interests fall within the field of cognitive neuroscience. I am generally curious about 1) learning, 2) language, 3) semantic knowledge and 4) neuroimaging. I am interested in how we learn and make sense of the complex visual, linguistic and auditory world around us. How do we learn language? How do we learn from, and extract meaning from complex visual, linguistic and auditory input? How do semantic systems and language systems interact? How can we understand the cognitive and computational mechanisms of learning and language using neuroimaging and computational models? These are just some of the many questions I am interested in pursuing.
I am also severely interested in neuroimaging techniques (MRI, EEG, MEG, etc.), their respective analyses and improvements to analyses (qualitatively and quantitatively). I am intrigued by how the brain can be broken down computationally and how this understanding influences our characterization of cognitive processes. Additionally, I am generally interested in and passionate about the structure-function relationship, open science, coding and statistics.
On top of being a student, I am a Project Coordinator in the Language, Environment and NeuroDevelopment (LEND) Lab under the mentorship of Julie M. Schneider, PhD where I have learned lots about EEG and the signal processing operations behind it and lead a team of other undergraduates in learning and conducting EEG experiments. I am also an honors thesis student in the Representations and Learning (ReLearn) Lab under the mentorship of Christopher Cox, PhD where I have delved deep into MRI, SL and much more.
Additionally, I am a big foodie and will eat practically anything. (Except raisins. Who wants a dried, shriveled grape when you can have a nice, juicy, good tasting one? They smell weird too.) I do enjoy my fair share of television; my favorite show is The Simpsons. In my free time, I enjoy walking around outside when the weather is nice and listening to my favorite song, “The Night Chicago Died” by Paper Lace, playing the violin (which I have been doing for 10+ years), and coding (check out some of my cool coding projects/resourcs on my GitHub or in the Learning & Resources section).
At the moment, I am working towards entering a collaborative and open-science driven graduate program in Cognitive Psychology and/or Cognitive Neuroscience with opportunities to enhance my knowledge of language, neuroimaging, statistics and data science as well as receive detailed training in being a scientist of the brain.

title: My Open Science
text: It is important to practice what you preach! (See Open Science). In this section, I provide open access to sites which house my current/in-progress and completed research. The following resources provide an in-depth account of a project-much more than a manuscript or presentation might be able to. Please check out Projects for brief descriptions of some of what I am working on at the moment.

title: My Open Science
text:
ORCID
ORCID or Open Researcher and Contributor ID is an important tool used to access and track researchers across publications and disciplines. Check out more information about ORCID here.

title: My Open Science
text:
GitHub
GitHub is an incredibly powerful tool for researchers, scientists and more across many fields. The role of GitHub can vary depending on the person. On my GitHub, you will find code used in a variety of projects, but I also use GitHub for writing (more on this soon!). I primarily work with Python, MATLAB and R and the majority of my GitHub consists of these languages. Click on the icon above to access my GitHub.

title: My Open Science
text:
OSF
The Open Science Framework (OSF) is a foundational tool in bolstering open science efforts. It is structured like a file folder system, with “Projects” being the main file, while subcomponents, like “Analysis” or “Code” being the files within. On my OSF, you will find a more detailed account of projects, an interface with GitHub to access code used in the project, and other components that typically make up a project, like the stimuli used and more. Click on the icon above to access my OSF.

title: Archive
text: Here you will find past projects that have been completed. There are other projects which have since been completed; however, the following descriptions are from projects that I felt significantly added to the characterization of my science and research interests.

title: Archive
section: Quality of Neural Data Between Two EEG Capping Approaches
text:
Quality of Neural Data Between Two EEG Capping Approaches
Given EEG’s relatively low cost, there eixists a variety of capping approaches scientists may use to conduct research. However, there are fundamental differences between brands, electrodes, amplifiers that effect data and data collection. In this project, I evaluated the qulitative and quantitive differences between BrainVision’s EasyCap and R-Net–two caps that differ in there implementation and data collection. For example, the R-Net uses passive electrodes whereas the EasyCap uses active electrodes. (The distinction between “active” and “passive” electrodes is the place of amplification of the signal). We found significant differences in the data processing operations used during preprocessing and identified qualititative differences across caps as well. This resultant poster from this project can be found here.

title: Current Projects
text: Below are brief synopses of current projects that I am working on. Naturally, there are other projects at various stages; however, the following descriptions are from projects which I felt significantly added to the characterization of my science and research interests.

title: Current Projects
section: The Architecture of Auditory Statistical Learning
text:
The Architecture of Auditory Statistical Learning
Statistical learning (SL) is the neuro-cognitive mechanism that the brain employs to identify, parse and extract meaning from continuous input by identifying statistical patterns such as transitional probabilites (TPs). SL can be observed across a variety of cognitive domains and is particularly relevant in the language domain. It has been shown that langauge acquisition occurs through SL. However, previous neuroimaging studies characterize the learning of meaning via auditory SL as static when, rather, learning occurs across the temporal domain, employing various neural regions across space. The focus of this current project is to idetify the changes in functional “states” during SL to uncover how changes in learning are supported at the neural level. To do this, we can use fMRI and a sliding window correlation analysis to observe how functionally connected networks and regions are implicated in learning across time.
Keywords: fMRI, statistical learning, langauge, dynamic functional connectivity

title: Current Projects
text:
Optimized Pipeline for Developmental ERPs
This project is partially funded by an LSU Discover Project Grant. This project involves examining data quality metrics for developmental EEG/ERP data and identifying optimized preprocessing operations from such data with the ultimate end goal of producing an open-access, easily executable pipeline for researchers. If you are interested in the in-progress pipeline, check out the GitHub repo here where a detailed wiki has been constructed of everything completed thus far. If you are interested in the analysis being used, check out that GitHub repo here.
In recent years, a call for standardization of EEG preprocessing methods has been amplified and studies aimed at identifying the best preprocessing criterion determined that there exists some limited range of parameters one can process EEG data through before compromising data quality, statistical significance and reproducibility. However, this research primarily consisted of adult EEG data. Given the exogenous and endogenous impacts of developmental populations on EEG data, a distinct evaluation of the best preprocessing methods for developmental data must be made. This is—in short—the foundation of the project.
Keywords: EEG, ERP, quality metrics, developmental

title: Archive
section: A Look at Rhyme’s Role in Word Learning in Adults
text:
A Look at Rhyme’s Role in Word Learning in Adults
Phonological and semantic cues have been shown to significantly bolster word learning by aiding in encoding. Previous behavioral examinations into this exact phenomena through rhyme have demonstrated such an outcome, yet, the speed and depth of rhyme’s aid in word learning is not quite understood. To uncover the true nature of rhyme’s role in word learning, we used EEG and ERP methods to characterize this phenomena. We specifically examined the N400 ERP component and found a significant attenuation across exposure to our paradigm and deduced that rhyme may serve as a more implicit faclitator of encoding. The resultant poster from this project can be found here.

title: Learn some stuff
text:
I have always felt that teaching a concept significantly increases one’s own understanding of that concept. Recently, I have been building learning materials for a myriad of different concepts. Most of them are in progress at the moment but below are some that have some substance to learn from.
These topics range from mathematical concepts, to coding and more. Stay tuned for details on how to contribute. An effort is currently being made to convert these resources into static sites of their own.

title: Learn some stuff
text:
Hidden Markov Models

  

What is a hidden Markov model (HMM)? How is it used in cognitive neuroscience? Here I provide an understanding of the concepts underlying HMMs, HMMs in general, and relevant literature that makes use of Markovian processes. Click on the image above to learn more about HMMs!

title: Learn some stuff
text:
Building MATLAB Functions

  

MATLAB is a powerful and widely used tool in cognitive neuroscience and building custom functions is important to optimizing your code. Here, I provide an understanding of building functions ranging in complexities.

title: Learn some stuff
text:
Brain Stimulation with Izhikevich Model

  

The Izhikevich Model, developed in 2003, allows us to quantify the dynamic nature of neuronal circutry. Here, I provide an introduction to the mathematical models behind neuronal activity and using this to understand brain stimulation.
